name: Fight for your right
description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

key_work.title: Occupy Wall Street protestors in New York City
key_work.brief_description: In 2011, the connectivity and speed of social media seemed promising for society and democracy. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube were integral to mobilising people and coordinating protest movements like Occupy Wall Street, which aims to create greater economic equality.

constellations_primary.name: Fight for your right
constellations_primary.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

start.title: Mr. Robot
start.brief_description: A young programmer, Elliot, suffers from a debilitating anti-social disorder and finds himself in the intersection between the cybersecurity firm he works for and the underworld organisations bringing down corporate America.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

constellations_other.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_other.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

constellations_other.name: Freedom from surveillance
constellations_other.description: Real world and cinematic authoritarianism and resistance explored through documentaries, Hollywood blockbusters, TV and videogames.

end.title: Riot
end.brief_description: A look at the 1970s Gay Rights Movement in Australia through the eyes of dedicated activist Lance Gowland. As Lance deals with his sexuality, he must also juggle work, family and relationships.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: While Mr Robot takes a dystopian approach to protest and resistance, Jeffrey Walker’s Riot tells the true story of the fight for LGBTQIA+ rights in Australia, specifically Sydney, where the Mardi Gras was established to fight for rights and showed protesting can be a form of celebration.

start.title: Riot
start.brief_description: A look at the 1970s Gay Rights Movement in Australia through the eyes of dedicated activist Lance Gowland. As Lance deals with his sexuality, he must also juggle work, family and relationships.

end.title: The Handmaid's Tale

video_links.name: The Handmaid's Tale: Series Trailer • A Hulu Original

end.brief_description: Set in a dystopian future, a woman is forced to live as a concubine under a fundamentalist theocratic dictatorship. A TV adaptation of Margaret Atwood’s novel.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

constellations_other.name: Painting pictures
constellations_other.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: While real-life protests were used as inspiration for Riot, the opposite exchange happens with The Handmaid’s Tale. The show’s iconic blood red costume and stark white hood have been adopted by real-life protestors, particularly those fighting for reproductive and women’s’ rights in America.

end.title: The Daily Show
end.brief_description: During the time of the protests, many late night TV shows reported on the protests, including The Daily Show while Jon Stewart was host. During the segment, Samantha Bee took a humourous approach and satirised participants.

start.title: The Daily Show

end.title: Full Frontal with Samantha Bee
end.brief_description: Samantha Bee breaks up late-night’s all-male sausage fest with her nuanced view of political and cultural issues, her sharp interview skills, her repartee with world leaders and, of course, her 10-pound lady balls.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: After 12 years as a correspondent on The Daily Show, Samantha Bee created her own late-night show in 2016, becoming the first woman to host a late-night satire show, which has been critically acclaimed. Aside from skewering political and cultural moments, Bee also uses the show to fight for women’s rights.

end.title: Law & Order: Special Victims Unit
end.brief_description: In the criminal justice system, sexually-based offenses are considered especially heinous. In New York City, the dedicated detectives who investigate these vicious felonies are members of an elite squad known as the Special Victims Unit. These are their stories.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: Dun, dun. It didn’t take long for the Law & Order TV franchise to create an episode around a crime at the Occupy Wall St camps. While they prepared the set and created a fake camp nearby the real camp, protestors occupied the set and #mockupy started trending.

links.description: Much of the Occupy Wall St footage captured by news outlets featured the famous Charging Bull statue in Wall St protected by police. This Wall St symbol of inequality also appears in Mr. Robot, when revolutionary hacker Darlen Alderson castrates it. Generally, Mr. Robot shares many of the concerns of the Occupy Movement.
